Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Ends of Oil: Changing Life in Earth Science, Extractive Industry, and Indigenous Communities in Alaska
Award.AbstractNarration:
How does oil as a resource and social and economic force end? And what comes next? In Alaska, these are some of the most pressing questions for northern communities facing dwindling dividends, aging pipelines, and eroding coastlines. This exploratory research project will examine how a variety of stakeholders - earth scientists, oil companies, state policy-makers, and Alaska Native peoples - are each responding to the fiscal, infrastructural, environmental, and cosmological ends of oil in Alaska and envisioning how life might carry on afterwards.

The aim of this proposed EAGER research is to make contact with these stakeholders, survey their engagements with the issue, visit field sites, and identify partners in order to better craft a collaborative, multi-sited research project on the ends of oil in northern Alaska. EAGER support will enable this exploratory research to incorporate local concerns into the design and implementation of a larger research project on "the Ends of Oil in Alaska."

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome Report

EAGER: Collaborative Research

The Ends of Oil: Changing Life in Earth Science, Extractive Industry, and Indigenous Communities in Alaska

David Bond (PI), Bennington College

July 1, 2016 – January 31, 2017 // NSF Award #: 1642016

 

Whether in dwindling dividends, aging pipelines, eroding coastlines, or new exploration projects, northern Alaska offers a compelling vantage point for understanding the social implications of fossil fuels today.

The purpose of this EAGER research was to initiate dialogue with rural Alaskan communities on how they are navigating concerns over the economic and environmental instabilities of oil, and to advance local insights on these questions into wider policy and scholarly projects. To do so, PI David Bond (Bennington College) traveled to communities in northern Alaska with PI Lucas Bessire (University of Oklahoma) and: 1) met with a variety of stakeholders, from earth scientists to oil company representatives, from state policy-makers to Indigenous leaders; 2) surveyed local engagements with the ends of oil, including the rising costs of gasoline and heating oil, the fluctuating migration patterns of keystone species, the Arctic monitoring of planetary CO2 emissions, and the projected local impacts from new drilling projects; 3) consulted with communities to develop and field-test experimental methods to conduct cutting-edge social research in collaboration with local communities; and 4) identified Alaskan institutions and local partners for future research projects on these themes. Together, these preliminary findings allowed us to incorporate local concerns and capacities into the design of a larger collaborative research proposal on petro-conclusions and post-petroleum society in Alaska.

PI Bond traveled to major cities in Alaska and a number of rural communities in northern Alaska in August 2016 in order to meet with local leaders and to explore the possibility of collaborating on research in the near future. Communities visited include: Anaktuvak Pass, Anchorage, Barrow, Fairbanks, Kaktovik, and Wainwright. We also visited a number of earth science experiments underway in Barrow and Kaktovik to learn more about how the Arctic offers a compelling lens from which to examine planetary change. Lastly, we met with a number if federal, state, municipal, and non-governmental agencies working on related topics to explore potential partnerships on future research, including: the Alaska Native Studies and Rural Development Department at UAF, the Center for Alaska Native Health Research at UAF, Cold Climate Housing Center, First Alaskans Institute, the Global Monitoring Division of NOAA, the North Slope Borough Department of Wildlife Management, UIC Science, and US Fish and Wildlife Service.

Presentations and publications currently in preparation that result from this research offer preliminary reflections and initial framings on a range of topics, from the experienced convergence of economic and environmental instabilities of oil in Alaska today to the rising storylines of changing life in the Arctic to the critical import of collaborative methods and community driven research.

This was an exploratory research project aimed at organizing a more effective theoretical and methodological foundation for future collaborative research. Within that frame, the preliminary findings from the early-stage research are as follows: 1) the proactive involvement of local and regional organizations in shaping environmental futures; 2) the contemporary genre of change in the North and the changing significance of the Arctic for global audiences; 3) the scripted inputs of local communities for analytical and industrial projects in the North and the resulting research fatigue of many communities in northern Alaska; and, 4) the practical and theoretical purchase of collaborative methods in social research today.
